ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I loved taking this course because it gave me a fresh perspective on the Gita despite having grown up with a lot of its learning being a Hindu
I developed a deep knowledge of the Bhagavad Gita and the ways in which it has been interpreted.
Better understanding of my own religion and The Gita
I learned more about the Hindu scripture the Bhagavad Gita, which in turn, also re-shaped my lifestyle and made me rethink my philosophy about a lot of things. I also learned how to use footnotes.
This class developed my reading and analysis skills. There were several readings each week that we were required to comment on.
Amazing insight into an important text. It is a spiritual guide everyone needs!
Insight into Bhagavad Gita and the nuances of indian philosophy
None
I learned important Sanskrit vocabulary terms like dharma and the atman as well as how the teachings of the Bhagavad Gita can be implemented into one's daily life through a variety of ways.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The biggest strength of the course is that it is once a week and allows you to post any questions you may have about a section before class so the professor can address it. It would be a little bit more engaging if we could also have discussions in class among students instead of only a one-way lecture from the professor
This was a great class. I wish there were Powerpoint slides to organize the discussion. Sometimes I felt lost in the middle of lecture and so having that structure would have been nice.

The strengths are Prof. Flick's deep and wide knowledge of the book. It could be improved only with slightly more student engagement  because of the lecture format, some students had their cameras off on Zoom all term. The lecture format really didn't bother me, though; it is the best vehicle for Dr. Flick's knowledge.
No weaknesses. Strengths: interesting readings, great lectures, Professor Flick and Nate the TA were both awesome.

A weakness fo the class was the length of the lectures. Perhaps engagement would improve if the class was taught twice a week for less time as opposed to almost two hours at a time per week. A strength of the class was the course load which was very manageable.
Very well structured for weekly engagement, without excessively time consuming assignments

Strengths - low workload, and gives you insights into Indian philosophy in a very chill manner
Weakness - I wish there was more engagement - the class was more interactive.

Weakness: the most boring class I've ever taken.
Strength: not too much work.

The weekly discussion posts were effective in allowing students to reflect on the readings and provide the professor with any questions that would be answered in class. Due to the large class size, it was difficult to promote small group discussion among peers.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The discussion board was a great way of engagement!
One great feature of the class was weekly Canvas discussion posts, where students write their takeaways from that week's reading of the Gita and of secondary sources.
Virtual was tough because it made it harder to focus, but Professor Flick and Nate did a great job.
I liked that the professor recorded all of his lectures so that I would be able to rewatch the lectures in case of an absence of class or technology issues.
The discussion sections were a good idea

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes a great class to take if you're interested in Hindu philosophy!
Anyone remotely interested in learning about Hinduism should definitely take this course!
Its a great class if you want to learn about Bhagavad Gita.
Absolutely. It was a fantastic, beneficial and enjoyable class.
Yes. Take this class. It's a great way to learn about another culture in a non-stressful setting.
100%. Prof Flick is an amazing mentor and a great scholar of this text
Yes, very chill class, easy to get an A, and is a good humanities gut
I would not

Yes. Very minimal workload- short weekly reading responses and 2 papers in total. A nice, relaxing course that allows you to learn a lot about yourself and is a nice break from other, more rigorous and intense courses at Yale

Yes, this course is very insightful and approachable in such a way that everyone has great potential to get something out of it. Your questions will always be answered to the best of the professor's ability.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Included a discussion board
Zoom lectures and Canvas posts
n/a
The virtual class was recorded for us to watch back at another time.
Discussions forums and live / virtual lecture
N/A
